questions.question: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in an array by index?
questions.explanation: Array access by index is constant time O(1) because we can directly calculate the memory address.

questions.question: Which data structure follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle?
questions.explanation: A stack follows LIFO where the last element added is the first one to be removed.

questions.question: Bubble sort has a time complexity of O(n²) in the worst case.
questions.explanation: Bubble sort compares adjacent elements and has O(n²) time complexity in worst and average cases.

questions.question: In a binary search tree, what is the maximum number of children a node can have?
questions.explanation: A binary tree by definition can have at most 2 children per node (left and right).

questions.question: What is the time complexity of binary search?
questions.explanation: Binary search eliminates half of the search space in each iteration, resulting in O(log n) complexity.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a primitive data type in most programming languages?
questions.explanation: Array is a composite/derived data type, not a primitive one.

questions.question: Inheritance allows a class to inherit properties and methods from multiple parent classes in all programming languages.
questions.explanation: Multiple inheritance is not supported by all languages. For example, Java supports single inheritance only.

questions.question: What is the key principle behind dynamic programming?
questions.explanation: Dynamic programming solves problems by breaking them into overlapping subproblems and storing results to avoid recomputation.

questions.question: Name one algorithm used to find the shortest path between two nodes in a weighted graph.
questions.explanation: Dijkstra's algorithm is a popular choice for finding shortest paths in weighted graphs with non-negative weights.

questions.question: Which control structure is used to execute a block of code repeatedly?
questions.explanation: Loops (for, while, do-while) are control structures designed for repetitive execution.
